attributes.title: Generative and preventative causal learning in continuous time

q1.value: Generative and preventative causal learning in continuous time (new stimuli)

q3.value: This study aims to explore whether and how people can make use of temporal information to learn generative and preventative causal connections in a continuous time setting.

q4.value: Based on past studies on inferring generative causal relationships, we hypothesise that human performance will be above chance on average and positively correlated with our normative Bayesian inference model.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: We have no between-subject manipulations.  Within subjects, participants are blind to the ground truth (the true generative causal structure) in each learning problem.

question.value: We have planned a fully within-subject experimental design in which participants must make judgments about 18 clips. These 18 clips constitute 3 (A connection: generative, non-causal, preventative) * 3 (B  connection: generative, non-causal, preventative) situations (see the figure below), with 2 clips in each situation.

q9.value: The on-screen position of A and B (above or below), and the order in which clicks cycle through response options (e.g., click once: generative, click twice: preventative, click three times: non-causal) will be randomised between participants. The order of 18 clips will be pseudorandomised between participants, with the constraint that two clips from the same causal connection pattern will not be presented sequentially.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Amazon Mechanical Turk (HIT Approval Rate for all requester's HITs: greater than 90%;  Number of HITs Approved: greater than 100; Location: United States). Participants will be paid $1 for participation plus will receive a 3 cent bonus for each correctly judged connection (the maximum payment for completing the 18 devices is thus $1.08, and participants in our pilot study gained an average bonus of $0.77 ). Participants must be at least 18 years old.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .9 power to detect a medium effect size (r=.4) at the standard .05 alpha error probability (two tails).

q15.value: We plan to recruit from mechanical Turk in batches of 9 (and the final batch will be 6) participants (so avoiding their higher fees for batches equal or larger than 10).  However, an inherent possibility of collecting data online is that some workers will hold onto a task and complete it later meaning we cannot always distinguish dropouts from delayed completes.  If this occurs we may end up with slightly (smaller than 5) greater number of participants than intended.  If this occurs, we will simply analyse this larger sample.

question.value:
We manipulate the form of two potential causal relationships in each test “device” and correspondingly present a different event sequence in each trial clip. Each connection can be generative, non-causal, or preventative yielding 9 unique device types. We generated 2 movie clip stimuli for each device using simulation in R. The final 18 trials were chosen to include 2 examples from each device and were subject to the constraint that no two activations of the same component overlap.  Note, in our clips, components activate for 350ms making overlapping activations rare but also perceptually ambiguous.

See the attached file for the encoding of activation times for A, B, and E in all 18 clips as well as one practice clip (non-causal A and generative B).

We will record participants' answers (generative, preventative, or non-causal) for each of the two connections in each trial, and record the time at which they make these judgments (relative to each 20 second trial).  We will also collect participants' age in years, gender (male, female, prefer not to say, other), and self reports of their level of engagement and how difficult they found the task (both on scales from 1 to 10).

We will compute the mean accuracy for generative, preventative and non-connection judgments for each participant and use this to compare participants against chance performance.  We will also compute the mean accuracy for each of the 18 trial types and use this to infer the relative difficulty levels for different trial types.

In our exploratory modelling, we plan to compare participant’s performance against a random responding baseline model, a normative Bayesian inference model, and one or several heuristic models. We will try to predict participants’ aggregate behaviour as well as individual levels.

See the attached figure for the predictions of our initial normative Bayesian inference model to each clip (no adding perceptual noise). See the attached html file for the algorithm of our initial normative Bayesian inference model.

q21.value: We will use standard p less than or equal to 0.05 criteria for inferences in our primary analyses.  We will use maximum likelihood to compare computational models with no or equal numbers of fitted parameters.  We will use the Bayesian Information Criterion or held-out cross-validation to compare models that have different numbers of parameters.

q22.value: Participants must pass an instruction comprehension check in order to start our task and the task is financially incentivized so we do not anticipate many non-attentive participants.  However, we will exclude from analysis any participant who provides the same judgment for all connections, on the basis that this is strongly indicative of rushing through rather than engaging with the task.

q23.value: If a subject does not complete the task, their data will not be stored and we will not include them in our analyses.

q24.value: We will record the time at which participants make their judgments within each trial. We will explore what evidence drives participants to confirm their beliefs and how participants' beliefs change dynamically.

q25.value: This pre-registration is based on a pilot experiment that was also pre-registered and documented in this project. We realised an overlapping problem in our original stimulus list (two activations of the same component were too close in time, so people actually can only detect one activation), and we did not record the actual causal path for each stimulus, which could be essential for model comparison. Therefore, we regenerated the stimulus list. Other parts remained the same as the previous pre-registration.

summary.value: This is a preregistration for a coordinated analysis of personality predictors of cognitive dispersion. The preregistration is attached using the template for secondary analysis of existing data.

registration_responses.summary: This is a preregistration for a coordinated analysis of personality predictors of cognitive dispersion. The preregistration is attached using the template for secondary analysis of existing data.

q1.value: Intergroup Differences in Intuitiveness of Religious and Atheist Scientists 2

q3.value: In this study, we aim at replicating our previous findings to examine whether people intuitively stereotype scientists as being atheist in contrast to other professions. In this replication, we will use the same conjunction fallacy paradigm as in our previous study (see the preregistration document Intergroup Differences in Intuitiveness of Religious and Atheist Scientists for more detail about the design). This time, however, we will introduce a new control group of novelists in addition to scientists. Also, we will modify the descriptions of the targets. Previously, both targets (scientists and authors) were presented as working at a top university. In this study, we will remove this information. This is because it is possible that people associate all academics (even authors working at a university) as being similar to scientists. That is, the description of the authors in our previous study might have not been an appropriate control category to scientists.

q4.value: In the light of our previous findings, we hypothesise that atheist participants would find atheist targets as more stereotypical than religious targets, but only when the targets represented a scientist. We expect no differences in atheist participants' judgements about target religiosity in the case of the novelist targets. We predict the same pattern of results for non-religious participants as for atheist participants, but with smaller effect sizes. Finally, we expect that religious participants would not display any biases and would judge both targets and their religiosity as typical (i.e., religious/atheist novelists/scientists).  That is, we predict a significant interaction among target religiosity, target type, and participants' religious identity.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Between-subjects design with religious identity (non-religious vs. religious vs. atheist), target type (scientist versus novelist), and target religiosity (religious vs. atheist) as factors (3 x 2 x 2).

q9.value: Participants from each religions/non-religious identity group will be randomly assigned to target type and target religiosity condition (novelist vs. scientist and religious or atheist novelist and religious or atheist scientist).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Data collection will be conducted through Prolific Academic Participant Panels online.  Parameters include UK residents, aged 18 or over, and identification as either religious, atheist, or other non-religious (e.g., agnostic, no religion).

q13.value: We will recruit 600 participants, 50 participants per cell.

q14.value: We ran a power analysis in G*Power software for small to medium effect sizes to achieve 80% of power.

question.value:
Religious identity will be manipulated by recruiting three groups of participants who identify themselves as religious, non-religious, or atheist. 

Further, target type will be manipulated by presenting participants with targets' descriptions:

For the novelist: Mo was always the storyteller in his class.  He was interested in spinning creative plots and describing people's innermost thoughts and characteristics.  Nowadays his friends would alternately describe him as quiet or talkative, depending on the company and whether he was discussing his favourite books and short stories.

For the scientist: Mo was always one of the most intelligent kids in his class.  He was curious about how the world worked and interested in learning new things.  Nowadays his friends would alternately describe him as quiet or talkative, depending on the company and whether he was discussing his favourite research findings.

Finally, targets' religiosity will be manipulated by giving participants an option to decide how likely it is that the target presented in the description is either a scientist and how likely it is that the scientist is also religious (religious-scientist condition) or that the scientist is atheist (atheist-scientist condition). The same will be manipulated for the novelist (religious-novelist condition and atheist-novelist condition). Each participant will be presented with a single condition.

We will measure participants' judgements of how likely they think the target presented in the description is: a scientist, religious scientist, atheist scientist, a novelist, religious novelist, atheist novelist. This will be measured by asking participants to report their judgements on a scale from 1 (very unlikely) to 10 (very likely). We will collect two judgements per participants, e.g., participants will be asked: "What is the likelihood of the following statements? 1) Mo is a scientist 2) Mo is a scientist and is religious."

We will subtract participants' scale ratings (Mo is a religious scientist ratings minus Mo is a scientist ratings), to obtain a relative conjunction fallacy score. That is, positive scores will indicate that participants committed the conjunction fallacy to a higher extent. For example, positive scores for the religious-scientist condition would mean that participants exhibit an intuitive judgements and consider scientist to be religious. The mean scores will be then computed per participant.

We will use a between-subjects ANOVA (3 x 2 x 2), with religious identity, target type, and target religiosity as categorical predictors. The likelihood of each target (scientist/novelist) being religious/atheist or just being the target (scientist/novelist) will be measured on a scale as a continuous dependent variable.

q20.value: If the dependent variable turns out to be non-normally distributed, we will consider applying Tukey criterion or logarithmic transformation. Non-parametric tests will be considered in the case of not obtaining normally distributed data after transformations.

q21.value: We will use alpha level of .05. Follow-up analyses for significant interactions will be conducted using Holm-Bonferroni correction to correct for multiple comparisons. This correction method is neither liberal nor conservative.

q22.value: We will use an attention check and exclude participants who failed it.

q23.value: Participants who do not complete the main measures (conjunction fallacy tasks) will be excluded from the final analysis.

q24.value: In addition to the main paradigm, we will also include a number of questionnaires to measure: Participants' perception of a science-religion conflict, belief in science scale (Farias, et al. 2013), religious fundamentalism scale, identification with science and religion, beliefs about evolution, and beliefs in God. In our exploratory analyses, we will use those measures as covariates. We will do the same with demographic variables (gender, age, occupation, status).

registration_responses.q21: We will use alpha level of .05. Follow-up analyses for significant interactions will be conducted using Holm-Bonferroni correction to correct for multiple comparisons. This correction method is neither liberal nor conservative.
registration_responses.q22: We will use an attention check and exclude participants who failed it.
registration_responses.q23: Participants who do not complete the main measures (conjunction fallacy tasks) will be excluded from the final analysis.
registration_responses.q24: In addition to the main paradigm, we will also include a number of questionnaires to measure: Participants' perception of a science-religion conflict, belief in science scale (Farias, et al. 2013), religious fundamentalism scale, identification with science and religion, beliefs about evolution, and beliefs in God. In our exploratory analyses, we will use those measures as covariates. We will do the same with demographic variables (gender, age, occupation, status).
registration_responses.q8.question: Between-subjects design with religious identity (non-religious vs. religious vs. atheist), target type (scientist versus novelist), and target religiosity (religious vs. atheist) as factors (3 x 2 x 2).
registration_responses.q12.question: Data collection will be conducted through Prolific Academic Participant Panels online.  Parameters include UK residents, aged 18 or over, and identification as either religious, atheist, or other non-religious (e.g., agnostic, no religion).
registration_responses.q16.question:
Religious identity will be manipulated by recruiting three groups of participants who identify themselves as religious, non-religious, or atheist. 

Further, target type will be manipulated by presenting participants with targets' descriptions:

For the novelist: Mo was always the storyteller in his class.  He was interested in spinning creative plots and describing people's innermost thoughts and characteristics.  Nowadays his friends would alternately describe him as quiet or talkative, depending on the company and whether he was discussing his favourite books and short stories.

For the scientist: Mo was always one of the most intelligent kids in his class.  He was curious about how the world worked and interested in learning new things.  Nowadays his friends would alternately describe him as quiet or talkative, depending on the company and whether he was discussing his favourite research findings.

Finally, targets' religiosity will be manipulated by giving participants an option to decide how likely it is that the target presented in the description is either a scientist and how likely it is that the scientist is also religious (religious-scientist condition) or that the scientist is atheist (atheist-scientist condition). The same will be manipulated for the novelist (religious-novelist condition and atheist-novelist condition). Each participant will be presented with a single condition.
registration_responses.q17.question: We will measure participants' judgements of how likely they think the target presented in the description is: a scientist, religious scientist, atheist scientist, a novelist, religious novelist, atheist novelist. This will be measured by asking participants to report their judgements on a scale from 1 (very unlikely) to 10 (very likely). We will collect two judgements per participants, e.g., participants will be asked: "What is the likelihood of the following statements? 1) Mo is a scientist 2) Mo is a scientist and is religious."
registration_responses.q18.question: We will subtract participants' scale ratings (Mo is a religious scientist ratings minus Mo is a scientist ratings), to obtain a relative conjunction fallacy score. That is, positive scores will indicate that participants committed the conjunction fallacy to a higher extent. For example, positive scores for the religious-scientist condition would mean that participants exhibit an intuitive judgements and consider scientist to be religious. The mean scores will be then computed per participant.
registration_responses.q19.question: We will use a between-subjects ANOVA (3 x 2 x 2), with religious identity, target type, and target religiosity as categorical predictors. The likelihood of each target (scientist/novelist) being religious/atheist or just being the target (scientist/novelist) will be measured on a scale as a continuous dependent variable.

attributes.title: Do Advertisements Boost Political Candidates’ Name Recognition and Favorability? Evidence from a Randomized Field Experiment on Facebook

q1.value: Do Advertisements Boost Political Candidates’ Name Recognition and Favorability? Evidence from a Randomized Field Experiment on Facebook

q15.value: "Study Design Overview: This study looks at the effects of Facebook (FB) ads on the advertising candidate’s name recognition and support in trial ballot heats. The ads were served on Facebook beginning on Monday, October 8, 2012 and ending Friday, October 12, 2012. Phone interviews with treatment and control subjects began on October 13 and ended October 15. This document was prepared prior to the launch of the survey. Subjects: Subjects are registered voters living in a state legislative district. The campaign first supplied us with a list of voters in its district. We then generated clusters of individuals with unique ages (in buckets of two years each; e.g., ‘30-31’ years old, ‘32-33’, etc. all the way to a final category of ‘65 and over’), genders, and cities. At the campaign’s request we removed individuals under the age of 30 and over the age of 75 from the study, leaving 32,029 voters assigned to 1,220 clusters across distinct combinations of 18 age ranges, 34 towns, and 2 genders. Some potential clusters are not represented because no individual on the voter file fell into all three categories. Assignment: We blocked clusters into groups of five based on cluster size (which ranged from one person to five hundred), then age range, then town, and finally gender. Within these groups of five clusters, we assigned two clusters to the control condition and one each to our three treatments: the name recognition appeal, the character appeal, and the policy appeal. Our procedure thus randomly assigned 32,029 identifiable individuals to online treatments (ads) within 1,220 clusters, each distinctly targetable via the Facebook ad interface. Because the 244 blocks contain similarly sized clusters, our analysis uses difference-in-means comparisons rather than difference-in-totals (Horvitz-Thompson estimation). Outcome measurement: The calling house that conducted the survey removed duplicate phone numbers from the list we supplied, which in effect targets one voter per household. In order to estimate the individual level ATE, we will weight by household size. We expect these weights to have negligible effects on the results, as less than 10% of the sample is affected. Analysis Weights. Because the blocked random assignment gives subjects somewhat different probabilities of being assigned to a treatment, we begin by calculating the probability of treatment assignment for each subject. Consistent estimates are obtained by weighting each observation by the inverse of its probability (IPW) of being assigned to its treatment condition. Standard errors will be generated using randomization inference assuming constant treatment effects; this procedure will take clustered assignment (as well as blocking) into account. These results should be closely approximated by analyses that use robust cluster standard errors and dummy variables for blocks; in order to save time, we plan to use the latter method when presenting preliminary results. Outcomes. We plan to recode the survey responses in the following way. 1. Recognition of the candidate vs. not. 2. Opinion of the candidate. Our hypothesis test will use multinomial logit predicting positive, negative, vs. never heard of candidate. 3. Relative opinion of the candidate vs. the opponent. Subtract candidate’s score (+1 positive, 0 no opinion, -1 negative) from the score of the opponent. Ordered logit will be used to analyze the difference score. 4. Ballot heat: Ordered logit will predict preference for candidate, no preference, preference for opponent. 5. Ad recall: Recollection of seeing ads for the candidate online over the past week. Covariates. The voter file contains variables that we expect to be prognostic of outcomes: party registration, age, gender, and turnout in previous elections. In addition to presenting results without covariates, we will include these as covariates in order dampen sampling variability. Party registration, gender, and turnout will be coded as indicator variables. Age, age-squared, and an indicator for missing data will be used as regressors. Subgroups: We expect no treatment effect among those who report not using FB, although spillover effects from FB users are in principle possible. Our primary analysis will be restricted to respondents who report using FB, provided that the survey reveals similar proportions reporting FB use in treatment and control. If not, we will infer that FB reporting was primed by the preceding questions differently in treatment and control; in that case, we will estimate the CACE by dividing our ITT among all respondents by the proportion in the control group who report using FB. The candidate deploying the ads suggested to us that larger effects are expected among older FB users, who may be more responsive to the candidate’s appeals and more likely to attend to FB ads in general. This is consistent with some findings in the literature on online advertising. We plan to test the interaction between the treatment and a dummy variable indicating whether a subject is 65+."

attributes.title: Are NGOs Opportunistic? A Randomized Field Experiment

q1.value: Are NGOs Opportunistic? A Randomized Field Experiment

q2.value: Daniel Nielson | Ryan Bakow | Mike Findley | Alex Egbert | Brian Reed

q15.value: "While significant literature on NGO theory and behavior already exists, most of what has been written is anecdotal, produced within the NGO community, and based on small, non-random samples. The current body of research lacks independent and scientific study of NGO behavior Though there are some examples, these outliers are rare and difficult to generalize (see Reinikka and Svensson 2001). As NGOs become more influential in development, a more scientific understanding of their behavior becomes critical (Aldashev and Verdier 2010; Doh and Teegen 2002). In order to increase the body of scientific knowledge concerning NGO behavior, we perform a randomized field experiment designed to measure the extent of NGO opportunism. Variation in NGO type and function increases the difficulty of generalizing about NGO behavior (hence the need for a randomized controlled experiment). For some time, non-governmental organizations (NGOs) have played an important role in public good provision and development initiatives. Because most NGOs claim non-profit status, political neutrality, liberal ideology, and a normative agenda, NGOs are considered by many to be the ideal mechanism for success in these important assignments. In some cases, NGOs may be the only mechanism. Yet the term “NGO” can apply to wide range of organizations (Spar and Dail 2002). Indeed, the variation can be so great (and multi-dimensional) that two NGOs may have nothing in common besides their non-profit, non-government status. NGOs may be international or community-based, well-funded or non-funded, infrastructure-oriented or advocacy-oriented. In short, it is a mistake to treat NGOs as a black box. Furthermore, the nature of typical NGO projects does not lend itself easily to measurement and accountability. Traditional mechanisms of accountability employed in the for-profit sector are ineffective in the NGO-sector. NGOs may not be concerned with increasing revenue or maximizing profits. There are few established professional codes of conduct to compare across organizations. The outcome of NGO projects and initiatives are often non-quantifiable (Fowler 1996). As mentioned, this leads many to speculate about the effects of increased NGO population and competition for funding. Many are hopeful, assuming NGOs will cooperate, coordinate and be unaffected in pursuit of their organizational missions (Matthews 1997; Simmons 1998; Price 1998). Others are less optimistic, claiming that NGOs will behave opportunistically in order to survive in an uncertain environment (Cooley and Ron 2002; Aldashev and Verdier 2010). Many point to growing principal-agent problems between donors, NGOs, and constituents (Brown and Moore 2001; Doh and Teegen 2002). It is important to note that none of this necessarily suggests that NGOs are becoming inherently corrupt and dishonest, or that their altruistic missions have changed. It does suggest that as competition for donor funds increases and as NGOs become more populous, NGOs may need to behave selfishly or opportunistically in some domains for their own preservation. At times, self-interested NGO priorities may not agree with those of their donors or their constituents (Cooley and Ron 2002). The current study seeks to assess whether NGOs behave opportunistically in the context of establishing a partnership with a research institution for future projects and funding. We randomly assign five conditions across a large sample of NGOs (n > 10,000). In each condition, NGOs are informed (via email) about the possibility of a future partnership with the Political Economy and Development Lab (PEDL). At the end of the email, each NGO is asked to reply with the estimated reimbursement cost for the use of their staff members in the future partnership. Each treatment condition receives a different level of additional information about PEDL in the text of the email. We analyze the effect of this additional information on the estimated reimbursement cost. The extent to which the estimated reimbursement cost varies relative to the control condition is our measure of opportunistic behavior. "

q16.value: "This experiment yields itself to four specific hypotheses. (I) When an audit is promised to evaluate an eventual partnership between PEDL and an NGO, estimated reimbursement costs will increase as NGOs are more careful to account for even minor expenses related to the project. (II) Implied project competition will increase reimbursement cost as NGOs may not respond to market competition incentives, but instead may be motivated to signal credibility through higher costs. (III) Information revealing PEDL’s familiarity with NGO partnerships—suggesting minimal information asymmetry—should decrease estimated reimbursement cost. (IV) NGOs’ estimated reimbursement costs will increase when given information suggesting wealthy donors and abundant resources. Treatment 1, the Audit Condition, receives the following additional language: “But please be aware that all PEDL projects are subject to thorough audits, so any expenses in future partnerships will be carefully scrutinized.” This additional information should prompt NGOs to be more careful when they respond with their reimbursement cost per staff member per day. A prima facie expectation might be that NGOs will lower their estimates in wariness of being revealed to have submitted inflated bids. Alternatively, as NGOs are more careful in the calculation of their reimbursement cost, we might also expect that they will factor more expenses into their estimates. Thus, despite the logic behind the avoidance of being caught inflating bids, we expect estimates to increase in response to the Audit Condition. Additionally, because of the added accountability, we expect this treatment will also decrease response rates. Some NGOs may be discouraged from responding because they are unaccustomed to rigorous audits or lack the organization to handle them. Treatment 2, the Competition Condition, is designed to signal to the recipient NGOs that PEDL is considering the reimbursement cost estimates of multiple NGOs. The treatment implies that PEDL is most likely to partner with the NGO that provides the most competitive estimate. The additional language added to this e-mail is found here: “Also, please be aware that we are sending a similar email to many NGOs, so there may be competition for future partnerships.” Microeconomic theory suggests that competition should induce lower prices. Therefore, NGOs should submit lower bids in this condition. However, while NGOs have strong incentives to contract with PEDL for future partnerships, we suspect that NGOs operate with the understanding that credibility may be more important than cost in the non-profit sector. Furthermore, NGOs may operate with the understanding that higher reimbursement cost is a signal of credibility and competence. Based on these assumptions and against microeconomic expectations, we expect that NGOs will increase their reimbursement estimates in response to the Competition Condition. Treatment 3, the Prior Knowledge Condition, is designed to suggest minimal information asymmetry between the donor/partner and the local NGO. Often miscommunication and confusion results from information asymmetry, which leads to increased financial cost and inefficiency in development work. Implying that PEDL has partnered with NGOs before and is familiar with typical reimbursement costs should reduce confusion and push NGOs to be more careful calculating their estimates. The additional language for this treatment is as follows: “Also, please be aware that we have worked with NGOs in multiple countries, so we have become familiar with average personnel costs.“ We expect this additional information will prompt NGOs to lower their reimbursement estimates compared to the control group. Lastly, Treatment 4, the Big Money Condition, contains the following additional language: “Also, please be aware that past projects have been supported by more than $3 million in grants and contracts from donors including the Gates Foundation, the Hewlett Foundation, the World Bank, and the African Development Bank, so PEDL typically brings significant resources to partnerships.” This treatment suggests that PEDL is well funded and endowed with abundant resources. This provides an incentive for NGOs to inflate their reimbursement estimates because there are no institutional constraints or traditional ranges for reimbursement costs in development work. We expect that NGOs will behave opportunistically by increasing their reimbursement estimates in response to this treatment. We also suspect that response rates will increase due to this treatment. Because the information suggests there is significant money and resources available, we expect NGOs will be more confident in their chances of establishing a partnership. "

q17.value: "PROTOCOL 1. The experiment will be conducting on a sample of 31,324 NGOs in developing countries. The distribution of NGOs by country is given in the table below. The sample comes from an online directory of NGOs. All NGOs in the sample have an email address for their organization. Non-English speaking organizations are dropped from the sample. Region Frequency Africa 3,200 Asia Middle East 2,900 Europe 1,100 Latin America & Carribean 2,700 Oceana 100 Total 10,000 2. We randomly assign all NGOs into one of five conditions: the Audit Condition, the Competition Condition, the Prior Knowledge Condition, and Big Money Condition, and the Control Condition. We block randomize based on geographic region (according to the regions in the above table) and according to NGO type (according to the type classification listed in the NGO directory). We suspect these blocking covariables may affect how NGOs respond to the treatment conditions, though we have no prior hypotheses about directions of the relationships. Half the sample is assigned to the Control Condition. The remaining half is distributed uniformly across the remaining four conditions. 3. Each NGO in each condition receives an email expressing PEDL’s interest in a project partnership with the recipient NGO. The email requests that the NGO reply with the daily reimbursement cost expected by the recipient NGO for the use of their staff members for the project discussed in the email. NGOs in the Control Condition receive no additional information in their email. NGOs in one of the four treatment conditions receive the following information in identical locations at the end of the text of their email messages. The email for the baseline or control condition is copied here: Dear : My name is Dr. Daniel Nielson, and I am director of the Political Economy and Development Lab (PEDL) https://pedl.byu.edu/Pages/Home.aspx at Brigham Young University in the United States. PEDL performs systematic research to fight poverty and promote global development. We are collecting information about possible research partnerships. This is not an invitation for immediate collaboration, but the information you provide will help us plan future partnerships. If you are potentially interested, please direct us to your website or other information about your organization. Our projects generally last 3-6 months and involve 2-4 NGO staff members. We sometimes reimburse partners for their costs. To help us plan, if we were to arrange a research partnership with your organization, how much money (in U.S. dollars) would you require to fund each staff member per day? In other words, what is the personnel cost for one person’s work for one day? For now a detailed budget will not be necessary; a single summary estimate will suffice. You may reply directly to this message or click on the link below: Thank you for your willingness to respond to this e-mail. Sincerely, Daniel L. Nielson, PhD Director, Political Economy and Development Lab Brigham Young University Audit Condition: “But please be aware that all PEDL projects are subject to thorough audits, so any expenses in future partnerships will be carefully scrutinized.” Competition Condition: “Also, please be aware that we are sending a similar email to many NGOs, so there may be competition for future partnerships.” Prior Knowledge Condition: “Also, please be aware that we have worked with NGOs in multiple countries, so we have become familiar with average personnel costs.“ Big Money Condition: “Also, please be aware that past projects have been supported by more than $3 million in grants and contracts from donors including the Gates Foundation, the Hewlett Foundation, the World Bank, and the African Development Bank, so PEDL typically brings significant resources to partnerships.” 4. Emails are sent through Qualtrics are addressed to the NGOs’ names or acronyms. The reply-to address varies depending on the experimental condition but is a derivative of “pedl.partners@byu.edu,” and all emails include the digital signature of Daniel Nielson, the director of the Political Economy and Development Lab. The subject line for these emails is “Potential Research Partnership.” The invitation for NGOs to reply with their reimbursement cost estimate is fully sincere: PEDL is actively seeking partnerships with NGOs for future projects. The emails make clear that there is no promise of an immediate partnership. There is thus no deception in the email messages. 5. Two additional rounds of follow-up emails are sent to those emails that do not respond. The new emails are entitled “Potential Research Partnership Reminder,” begin with a brief reminder paragraph, and copy the original message, signaling that this is a follow-up email. 6. As responses are received, the cost estimates are recorded for each organization. For those organizations that respond without the cost estimate, follow-up emails will be sent using an email template adjusted to the questions or concerns of the respondent NGO. All NGOs who respond without a cost estimate will be referred back to the original email that was sent to them. No additional information about the project will be given in the follow-up message in a way that might alter the treatment. 7. We will follow up with those NGOs that provide acceptable reimbursement cost estimates (that do not show evidence of opportunism). PEDL will pursue a few active partnerships with promising organizations."

This provides an incentive for NGOs to inflate their reimbursement estimates because there are no institutional constraints or traditional ranges for reimbursement costs in development work. We expect that NGOs will behave opportunistically by increasing their reimbursement estimates in response to this treatment. We also suspect that response rates will increase due to this treatment. Because the information suggests there is significant money and resources available, we expect NGOs will be more confident in their chances of establishing a partnership. "
registration_responses.q17: "PROTOCOL 1. The experiment will be conducting on a sample of 31,324 NGOs in developing countries. The distribution of NGOs by country is given in the table below. The sample comes from an online directory of NGOs. All NGOs in the sample have an email address for their organization. Non-English speaking organizations are dropped from the sample. Region Frequency Africa 3,200 Asia Middle East 2,900 Europe 1,100 Latin America & Carribean 2,700 Oceana 100 Total 10,000 2. We randomly assign all NGOs into one of five conditions: the Audit Condition, the Competition Condition, the Prior Knowledge Condition, and Big Money Condition, and the Control Condition. We block randomize based on geographic region (according to the regions in the above table) and according to NGO type (according to the type classification listed in the NGO directory). We suspect these blocking covariables may affect how NGOs respond to the treatment conditions, though we have no prior hypotheses about directions of the relationships. Half the sample is assigned to the Control Condition. The remaining half is distributed uniformly across the remaining four conditions. 3. Each NGO in each condition receives an email expressing PEDL’s interest in a project partnership with the recipient NGO. The email requests that the NGO reply with the daily reimbursement cost expected by the recipient NGO for the use of their staff members for the project discussed in the email. NGOs in the Control Condition receive no additional information in their email. NGOs in one of the four treatment conditions receive the following information in identical locations at the end of the text of their email messages. The email for the baseline or control condition is copied here: Dear : My name is Dr. Daniel Nielson, and I am director of the Political Economy and Development Lab (PEDL) https://pedl.byu.edu/Pages/Home.aspx at Brigham Young University in the United States. PEDL performs systematic research to fight poverty and promote global development. We are collecting information about possible research partnerships. This is not an invitation for immediate collaboration, but the information you provide will help us plan future partnerships. If you are potentially interested, please direct us to your website or other information about your organization. Our projects generally last 3-6 months and involve 2-4 NGO staff members. We sometimes reimburse partners for their costs. To help us plan, if we were to arrange a research partnership with your organization, how much money (in U.S. dollars) would you require to fund each staff member per day? In other words, what is the personnel cost for one person’s work for one day? For now a detailed budget will not be necessary; a single summary estimate will suffice. You may reply directly to this message or click on the link below: Thank you for your willingness to respond to this e-mail. Sincerely, Daniel L. Nielson, PhD Director, Political Economy and Development Lab Brigham Young University Audit Condition: “But please be aware that all PEDL projects are subject to thorough audits, so any expenses in future partnerships will be carefully scrutinized.” Competition Condition: “Also, please be aware that we are sending a similar email to many NGOs, so there may be competition for future partnerships.” Prior Knowledge Condition: “Also, please be aware that we have worked with NGOs in multiple countries, so we have become familiar with average personnel costs.“ Big Money Condition: “Also, please be aware that past projects have been supported by more than $3 million in grants and contracts from donors including the Gates Foundation, the Hewlett Foundation, the World Bank, and the African Development Bank, so PEDL typically brings significant resources to partnerships.” 4. Emails are sent through Qualtrics are addressed to the NGOs’ names or acronyms. The reply-to address varies depending on the experimental condition but is a derivative of “pedl.partners@byu.edu,” and all emails include the digital signature of Daniel Nielson, the director of the Political Economy and Development Lab. The subject line for these emails is “Potential Research Partnership.” The invitation for NGOs to reply with their reimbursement cost estimate is fully sincere: PEDL is actively seeking partnerships with NGOs for future projects. The emails make clear that there is no promise of an immediate partnership. There is thus no deception in the email messages. 5. Two additional rounds of follow-up emails are sent to those emails that do not respond. The new emails are entitled “Potential Research Partnership Reminder,” begin with a brief reminder paragraph, and copy the original message, signaling that this is a follow-up email. 6. As responses are received, the cost estimates are recorded for each organization. For those organizations that respond without the cost estimate, follow-up emails will be sent using an email template adjusted to the questions or concerns of the respondent NGO. All NGOs who respond without a cost estimate will be referred back to the original email that was sent to them. No additional information about the project will be given in the follow-up message in a way that might alter the treatment. 7. We will follow up with those NGOs that provide acceptable reimbursement cost estimates (that do not show evidence of opportunism). PEDL will pursue a few active partnerships with promising organizations."

attributes.title: Randomized Impact Evaluation Of Afghanistan’s National Solidarity Programme –Village Benefit Distribution Analysis”

q1.value: Randomized Impact Evaluation Of Afghanistan’s National Solidarity Programme –Village Benefit Distribution Analysis”

q2.value: Andrew Beath | Fotini Christia | Ruben Enikolopov

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: This pre-analysis plan for the Village Benefit Distribution Analysis (VBDA) specifies methodologies and specifications to be employed in testing hypotheses pertaining to the impact of institutional changes generated by the National Solidarity Programme (NSP) and related interventions on local governance outcomes. The plan was written prior to data analysis and pre-commits the authors to defined specifications for estimating impacts. The plan is structured around four sections, one table, and three appendices. Section II provides an overview of the study, detailing the nature of the treatment and associated interventions, the sample, and the experiment deployed to generate data for the study. Section III lists the hypotheses for the study. Section IV describes the methodology and specifications to be employed in hypothesis testing. Table I lists the hypotheses and indicators for the study. Appendices I – II list questions included in the Village Benefit Distribution Surveys and Appendix III lists questions from the Second Follow-Up Survey that are to be used in the analysis. This pre-analysis plan for the Village Benefit Distribution Analysis (VBDA) specifies methodologies and specifications to be employed in testing hypotheses pertaining to the impact of institutional changes generated by the National Solidarity Programme (NSP) and related interventions on local governance outcomes. The plan was written prior to data analysis and pre-commits the authors to defined specifications for estimating impacts.

q16.value: The analysis is to be structured around a test of five hypotheses, which are grouped into three ‘families’: Family A – Quality of Targeting H1: Intervention improves the targeting by village leaders of provided benefits to vulnerable populations in the village, as measured by characteristics of benefit recipients H2: Intervention improves the targeting by village leaders of provided benefits to vulnerable populations in the village, as assessed subjectively by villagers Family B – Elite Capture H3: Intervention reduces embezzlement of benefits by village leaders H4: Intervention reduces nepotism in distribution of benefits by village leaders Family C – Decision-Making Process H5: Intervention results in more participatory decision-making process.

q17.value: The study seeks to test the above hypotheses and thereby address whether the institutional changes imposed by NSP, as well as variations in institutional rules, alter the behavior of village leaders. Indicators for testing hypotheses are generated using data collected on Day 3 of the wheat distribution and are grouped according to hypothesis. The aggregate effect of the intervention on each of these five indicator groups is estimated, via OLS, as the average of the effects for the constituent indicators, with standard errors estimated using five systems of seemingly unrelated regressions. To ensure robustness to different assumptions concerning unobserved outcomes of the distribution, multiple hypothesis tests are run using different sample adjustments. The following sections provide a summary of the methodology to be employed in the estimation of intervention impacts. Sub-section i describes the estimation of treatment effects; sub-section ii details the specifications to be employed in hypotheses tests; subsection iii details the specifications for estimating impacts of variation in treatment and distribution modalities; sub-section iv describes sample adjustments that are to be made to ensure the robustness of the analysis to uncertainty concerning unobserved outcomes of the distribution; and sub-section v covers procedures for addressing cases of missing data or questions with limited variation.

attributes.title: Status on the Street: A Field Experiment on the Effect of Signaling Socio-Economic Status on Pro-social Behavior

q1.value: Status on the Street: A Field Experiment on the Effect of Signaling Socio-Economic Status on Pro-social Behavior

q2.value: Daniel Nielson | Matthew Brigham | Mike Findley | Madeleine Gleave | Brock Laney | Peter Carroll

q15.value: In this project we seek to understand how people in a developing country context respond to indications of socio-economic status. Following Milgram’s work on obedience, Ariely’s work on theft, and Levine’s work on cultural embeddedness, we seek to understand the effects of signaling different levels of socio-economic status on peoples’ behavioral response to requests that they perform a pro-social task. Conducting a field experiment in a relatively corrupt country, we signal different levels of status to subjects with words and dress. Then, we measure their behavior in response to the confederate’s request for a favor that involves purchasing cellphone airtime with the confederate’s money. Specifically, we investigate whether people are more likely to comply with a request for assistance from people they perceive to have higher levels of socio-economic status. We randomly assign status at three levels: student, aid worker, and businessperson. We also randomly assign nationality/race and gender in a full factorial design to investigate the causal effects of race and gender in conjunction with varied projections of status.

q16.value: "Where compliance is acceptance of the solicitation for assistance with a requested favor, we expect to find higher levels of compliance to researchers displaying cues of higher levels of status. We hypothesize that: H1: (Status Hypothesis) We expect subjects to be more likely to assist researchers representing businesspeople compared to aid workers and more likely to help aid workers compared to students. We hypothesize that subjects will comply at higher rates to cues of higher socio-economic status, and at lower rates to cues of lower socio-economic status. H2: (Gender Hypothesis) We expect subjects to assist men more frequently than women. H3: (Theft Hypothesis) We expect subjects to steal most often from the researcher signaling white, foreign, male businessperson or aid worker, and steal least often from the researcher signaling Ugandan, local, female student. We expect relatively frequent thefts. H4: (Embeddedness Hypothesis) Because of the level of embeddedness of Ugandans with fellow Ugandans, Ugandan subjects should be less likely to assist American researchers and more likely to assist Ugandan researchers. H5: We expect heterogeneous treatment effects in the following set of subjects and conditions: - We expect female subjects to assist male researchers at rates lower than male subjects to assisting male researchers - We expect male subjects to assist female researchers at rates higher than male subjects to assisting male researchers - We expect elderly subjects will assist researchers at rates lower than young adult and adult subjects."

q17.value: "To gather the data for this field experiment, researchers will be positioned in predetermined areas through the city of Kampala. Within each area are either three or four locations where the confederate and the recorder are positioned to approach subjects, according to the protocol detailed below. On a particular day, the area of research is chosen based on convenience; however, treatments are assigned to specific locations randomly. On each day of research at midday, researchers rotate locations based on the randomization scheme. Treatments In this study, there are three treatments and two main subcategories across all of the treatments. The treatments are businessperson, aid worker, and student signaling different levels of socio-economic status. These treatments are signaled to subjects verbally and through appearance. For each of the treatments there is a corresponding line in the script used to signal that the confederate represents one of the treatment conditions (see script below). Confederates are also dressed in the clothes that are commonly associated with each of the treatments: dress clothes (i.e. suits) for the businessperson treatment, business casual for the aid worker treatment, and casual clothes for the student treatment. Each treatment is also divided into subcategories that are shared across the treatments. The subcategories are female and male, and local and foreigner. Local Ugandan citizens of both genders are hired to be confederates and recorders along with American researchers of both genders. Treatment subcategories are designated on a particular day by convenience but assigned randomly to given locations. We will gather data for each combination of treatment and subcategory so we will be able to employ a full factorial design. This will allow us to compare each treatment and subcategory combination to all of the other treatment and subcategory combinations in our analysis. Randomization Scheme In areas throughout downtown Kampala, locations are determined and numbered in advance. During the location scouting, locations are numbered based on the order in which they were found. The three treatments then are randomly assigned to the predetermined locations (i.e. the businessperson treatment is randomly assigned to location 2 of a particular area on a particular day). Thus, while the area of work is determined by convenience on a particular day, the treatments are randomly assigned to the research locations within an area. We maintain that this process of approaching people on the street at various locations within various areas at time intervals determined in the protocol is a particularly random method of sampling. This, coupled with the random assignment of treatment type to the research location, allows each subject to have an equal chance of being assigned any of the experimental conditions. Protocol 1. Researcher stands in location and the recorder takes his/her position. 2. Recorder measures 2 minutes and at the end of that period the researcher contacts the closest person (to the researcher’s right, if there is more than one person). a. The researcher approaches a subject: i. recorder begins timing the encounter, ii. the subject asks a question or objects (ex. “No, I cannot, please” or “No, I do not want to, please”), 1. see response scenarios below; b. The subject goes to buy airtime: i. recorder begins timing the subject, ii. recorder records the amount of time elapsed in the encounter, iii. after 8 minutes, the encounter is recorded as “theft” if the subject has not returned; c. The subject refuses to buy airtime: i. the response is coded appropriately, ii. the recorder begins the stopwatch and the researcher initiates another encounter after 2 minutes has passed. If the interaction with the subject deviates substantially from the above situations, i.e. the subject persists in asking questions which researchers cannot answer without violating the protocol, i.e., he or she offers to give researcher a ride, acts erratically, etc., the researchers tells the subject “never mind,” ends the interaction, and the observation is coded as a “drop.” Drops are later checked to verify that they are randomly distributed and not sensitive to treatments. After the researcher has coded the response, the pair of researchers wait 2 minutes before selecting the next subject, repeating step 2. Script Initial Contact “Sebo/Nyabo: [I need to get to a meeting with some fellow students/ I need to get to a meeting with some other NGO workers/ I need to get to a business meeting] and my driver was supposed to come here and pick me up. I need to call him, but I am out of airtime. I would go buy some, but I need to stay here because he is coming. Can please you go buy 1,000 shillings of MTN airtime for me? Thank you.” Contact upon return “Thank you. This is for your help” (hands the subject 500/= shillings). Response Scenarios 1. Subject Declines Researcher Response: “Please? It will not take long.” 2. Subject Declines a Second Time Researcher Response: “OK. Thank you.” 3. Subject Hesitates Researcher Response: “Please? It will not take long.” 4. Subject asks why/for more information Researcher Response: “My driver might be coming and I cannot miss him. Can you please? It will not take long.” 5. Subject offers his/her own phone Researcher Response: “Thank you, but my driver will only answer if he sees a number he recognizes, so I need to call him from my phone.” 6. Subject offers to give researcher a ride Researcher Response: “No, thank you. Can you help me please?” 7. Subject returns with the money, but no airtime Researcher Response: “What happened?” Subject responds that he/she could not find a station Researcher Response: “Can you try again please? It will not take long.” 8. Subject does not return Researcher Response: After 8 minutes, the observation is coded as a theft. Data Analysis Plan The primary test for experiments is a simple difference-of-means test, comparing the outcome of interest in the treatment group to the control group. Because we employ a full factorial design, we are able to compare a single treatment and subcategory combination (Aid Worker, Female, Ugandan) or a single treatment (Businessperson or not) to all of the other treatment and subcategory combinations pooled; this makes the difference-of-means test especially useful. In addition to this testing, we will also check for heterogeneous treatment effects in the areas listed in the fourth hypothesis. Logit analysis with covariates for subject type (gender, approximate age, neighborhood) will be employed as robustness checks."
